answers.answerText: A. Hypo-reflectivity in outer nuclear layer

answers.explanation:
The abnormalities found on this OCT are:

1. Ovoid hyporeflective spaces with hyperreflective borders in the outer nuclear layer

2. Subretinal hyper-reflective material

3. Loss of ellipsoid layer

There is no intra-retinal or subretinal fluid found on this OCT image.

![](/content/media/ort-labelled.webp)

questions.title: Question 1
questions.text:
![](/content/media/retina-32-1.webp)

What abnormality is NOT visualized in the patient’s OCT image?

questions.title: Question 2
questions.text:
![](/content/media/retina-32-3.webp)

What structures are the yellow arrows pointing to?

answers.explanation:
The yellow arrow is designating outer retinal tubulations.

​Outer retinal tubulations (ORT) are degenerated photoreceptor outer segment arranged on OCT in a circular or tubular shape. These areas of atrophy are associated with a variety of chronic macular diseases and occurs in outer retinal layer degenerative processes. The take home message here is not to misinterpret these ORTs as intra-retinal fluid. ORT are characterized by hypo-reflective spaces surrounded with a ring of hyper-reflectivity located specifically in the outer nuclear layer. Recently, the hyper-reflective borders have histologically been characterized as external limiting membrane and photoreceptor mitochondria.

References: Litts KM, Messinger JD, Dellatorre K, Yannuzzi LA, Freund KB, Curcio CA. Clinicopathological correlation of outer retinal tubulation in age-related macular degeneration. JAMA Ophthalmol 2015;133(5):1353-67.

questions.title: Question 3
questions.text: What disease is commonly associated with outer retinal tubulations?

answers.explanation:
The incidence of outer retinal tubulations increases with time in patients with wet-AMD and other chronic macula diseases. One study, for example, found outer retinal tubulations in 7% of nAMD patients at 1 year of follow-up, whereas the incidence was 31% at year 3. Outer retinal tubulations are associated with worse visual acuity, larger area of atrophy and decreased contrast sensitivity in nAMD patients compared to eyes without outer retinal tubulations.

References:

1. Takagi S, Mandai M, Miyamoto N, Nishida A, Hirami Y, Uyama H, et al. Incidence of outer retinal tubulation in eyes with choroidal neovascularization under intravitreal anti-vascular endothelial growth factor therapy in a Japanese population. Clin Ophthalmol 2017;11:1219-25.

2. Iaculli C, Barone A, Scudieri M, Giovanna Palumbo M, Delle Noci N. Outer Retinal Tubulation: Characteristics in Patients With Neovascular Age-Related Macular Degeneration. Retina 2015;35(10):1979-84.

questions.title: Question 4
questions.text:
![](/content/media/retina-32-4.webp)

What is the treatment of choice for outer retinal tubulations?

answers.explanation: No treatment is required for patients with outer retinal tubulations as they remain stable over the course of time. Therefore, it is critical to differentiate these atrophic areas apart from intra-retinal fluid to minimize unnecessary treatment.

title: Case 32
patientPresentation: A 68-year-old female with age-related macular degeneration is referred with gradual decreased vision. She was previously receiving anti-VEGF injections. The patient has no notable past medical or ocular history; Her vision is 20/25 OD and 20/400 OS. Her OS OCT macula is shown below
footer:
### Learning Objectives:

1. To diagnose and recognize outer retinal tubulations by their location in the outer nuclear layer, hyper-reflective demarcation, and association with chronic outer retinal degenerative conditions.
